Looping in LESS js

01 Mar 2014

Hey this is a draft

What is LESS?

In case you have been living under a rock - LESS is what's known as a CSS preprocessor. It takes code in .less files and generates equivalent .css files to be used in your HTML. The LESS syntax is a superset of CSS syntax and allows for features such as variables, mixins, and functions.

All it boils down to is syntactic sugar for CSS.

Mix-ins

Before we jump into making loops, we first need to understand how to use mix-ins.

Mix-ins in LESS are the semi-equivalent of functions in other languages. They allow for code reuse. You create a class and then can "call" that class inside of other CSS rules.

To create a mix-in you need to start with a class. Let's for example use a class that adds an inner shadow.

.inner-shadow {
    box-shadow: inset 0 0 10px #000;
}

Now let's say we want to add this inner shadow effect to some elements in our HTML.

.jumbotron {
    border-radius: 4px;
    background-color: #CCC;
    .inner-shadow; /* <-- add in this line */
}

code {
    border-radius: 2px;
    padding: 0.1em 0.3em;
    .inner-shadow; /* <-- and this line */
}

Hmmmm... well it gave us the inner shadow. Unfortunately the shadow stretches way too far on the code elements. It may look alright on our .jumbotron but code elements tend to be small/inline bits. 10px of inner shadow is simply too much for them.

We can fix this by adding a paramater to our mixin -- just like it were a function.

.inner-shadow(@spread) {
    box-shadow: inset 0 0 @spread #000;
}

And then we call the mixin with parameters...

.jumbotron {
    border-radius: 4px;
    background-color: #CCC;
    .inner-shadow(10px);
}

code {
    border-radius: 2px;
    padding: 0.1em 0.3em;
    .inner-shadow(2px);
}

Now the .jumbotron has 10px of shadow and code has only 2px of shadow.

Making a Loop

LESS does not have the standard loop constructs like in other languages. There is no for loop or while loop.

for ( var i = 1; i <= 10; i++ ) {
    console.log( 'And a ' + i );
}

The language is designed in a functional-language style. That means instead of using loops, we use recursion.

Most programmers are trained with this imperative mindset on looping so when they start working with LESS the equivalent construct may not be immediately obvious.
